</td>
<td style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;vertical-align: bottom" valign="bottom" width="33%">

<tr>
<td style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;vertical-align: top" valign="top">
<table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;border-collapse: separate" width="100%">
<tr>
<td class="editors_note" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;padding: 0px 40px 16px 40px; border-left: 2px solid #353535; border-right: 2px solid #353535; border-bottom: 2px solid #353535; border-collapse: collapse; border-radius: 0px 0px 10px 10px;">
<div style="font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;">
<div>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>Good morning. </strong>Today’s Editor’s Note is being replaced by a love letter to TikTok, an app that, while not perfect, has brought me a great deal of enjoyment the last few months.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">What makes TikTok so refreshing is that it’s one of the few places left where celebrity doesn’t matter. Users respond most to regular people with extraordinary talent (like our very own <a href="https://www.tiktok.com/@morningbrew/video/7013107425473465605?is_copy_url=0&is_from_webapp=v1&sender_device=pc&sender_web_id=6897986481718085126" class="link" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Dan Toomey</a>).</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">This says everything you need to know: The second-most followed person on Instagram is Cristiano Ronaldo. The second-most followed person on TikTok is <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2021/06/02/style/khaby-lame-tiktok.html?utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Khaby Lame</a>, a 21-year-old former factory employee in Italy who hilariously mocks “life hack” videos. Your social currency on TikTok is your ability to create A+ content <em>on TikTok</em>—it doesn’t matter whether you’re a soccer star or an assembly line worker. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">When I ask people why they’re not on TikTok, by far the most common response is, “I fear I’d like it so much that I’d spend all my time on it.” A) That's a ridiculous thing to say and b) come up with a solution because you're missing out.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;font-family:flood-std, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;font-size:16px;font-weight:500">—Neal Freyman</p>
</div>
</div>
</td>

</tr>
</table>
</td>
</tr>

<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">...Or warmer, or any temperature your body needs it to be, really, thanks to <a href="https://eightsleep.com/cover?utm_source=morningbrew&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_campaign=daily&utm_content=q4-2021-10-3" class="link" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">the Pod Pro by Eight Sleep</a>. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">The Pod Pro<strong> </strong>is<strong> the most advanced solution on the market for thermoregulation</strong>. It comes in the handy form of a mattress cover, so no need to switch your mattress to catch better z’s.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Scientists say there’s no single temperature that gets you deep sleep. Instead, body temperature needs to change throughout the night. <p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Stats coming in hot (or cool): <strong>Eight Sleep users fall asleep up to 32% faster and have 40% fewer sleep interruptions</strong>. Athletes also use the cooling tech for improved sleep. <td class="column" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;font-size: 0px; padding: 25px; word-break: break-word;">
<div style="font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;">
<h1 style="margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:24px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left">
Icebreakers With...TikTok Star Nick Cho
</h1>
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/10/01/icebreakers-with-tiktok-star-nick-cho?utm_source=morning_brew" style="text-decoration:none; border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="Photo of Nick Cho" style="border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/9ac74e9e4e0f269c212d77dc589dffeaaf6d4d08-2696x1522.jpg?w=670&q=70&auto=format">
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:16px;">
<small>
<em>Nick Cho</em>
</small>
</p>
</a>
<div>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Nick Cho, known as “<a href="https://www.tiktok.com/@yourkoreandad?utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Your Korean Dad</a>” on TikTok, is a comedian and self-proclaimed “king of weird analogies.” His day job is working at the SF-based <a href="https://www.wreckingballcoffee.com/?utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">coffee chain</a> he and his wife founded in 2011 but, with almost 3 million followers on TikTok and a newly launched YouTube channel, making wholesome social content is starting to become a full-time job.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Morning Brew got deep with Nick.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>What’s on your coffee shop’s playlist?</strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Back in 2001 or 2002, when I got my first iPod, I bought it at the store and when I got home I realized it already had music on it. Someone had bought it and returned it. When I looked at the playlist, it was all these hits from the ’80s and ’90s. And that has been my go-to coffee shop playlist for 20 years. There's Guns N' Roses on it. There's Van Halen, Paula Abdul.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Whenever I'm working at the cafes, it's only a matter of time before the baristas get fed up with the mix. We call it “Kwon's mix” because you know how you can name iPods or iPhones? The iPod was called Kwon’s iPod.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>If you didn't have to sleep, how would you spend the extra eight hours?</strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">I would be driving to different places. So I could spend every day somewhere new.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>What does your typical day look like?</strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">I don't eat breakfast when I wake up. I make cappuccinos for my wife and for myself—mostly for her. Then I go to the gym. Then I start working on whatever I'm working on. Lately, it's thinking about what to make for my TikTok. I have managers now, like Hollywood management. It's very strange.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">There’s one thing in my daily routine I feel immensely guilty about, so maybe talking about it will help me process. But, I have to be able to make space to just sort of “be” and either go for a walk or go to the gym or just chill. For example, I don't get massages on a regular basis, but the other day, I was like, I think I need a massage. And I had this flood of ideas that happened while I was getting a massage. And that's super self-indulgent. But for better or for worse, I can't produce if I don't take this time. And it's something that I'm struggling with and trying to figure out right now. You know, it's like Korean guilt. Like, I'm not sweating enough or not working hard enough.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>How do you manage that guilt?</strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">The first thing for me is realizing that guilt is okay. But it's not probably productive or helpful for me to feel too guilty. It’s almost like the Jiminy Cricket on your shoulder or this little voice in your head. We’re not supposed to shut those away.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>Are you someone that, when you are with people, you immediately start asking deep questions?</strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Yeah, I like to just get into it. That's sort of my style.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><em>This interview has been edited and condensed for clarity.</em></p>
</div>

<td align="left" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;font-size: 0px; padding: 10px 0px; word-break: break-word;">
<table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;color: #353535; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 13px; line-height: 22px; table-layout: auto; width: 100%; border: none;" width="100%">
<tr>
<td width="33%" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt">
<div style="text-align: center; background: linear-gradient(90deg, #ffe62e 25%, #0f9046); background-color: #1c7ff2; line-height: 4px; font-size: 4px; width: 100%; margin: 20px 0;">
 
</div>
</td>
<td style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;border: 2px solid #353535; background: white; margin: 0px; padding: 10px;">
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;word-break: keep-all; word-wrap: normal; text-align: center; text-transform: uppercase; font-family: Georgia, 'Times New Roman', Times, serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 16px; line-height: 18px; color: #353535; padding: 0px; margin: 0px;">
WORK LIFE
</p>
</td>
<td width="33%" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt">
<div style="text-align: center; background: linear-gradient(90deg, #2b9295, #1c7ff2); background-color: #1c7ff2; line-height: 4px; font-size: 4px; width: 100%; margin: 20px 0;">
 
</div>

<tr class="">
<td class="column" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;font-size: 0px; padding: 25px; word-break: break-word;">
<div style="font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;">
<h1 style="margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:24px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left">
I Used to Call Them Coworkers. Now I'm Their Manager.
</h1>
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/10/01/make-it-work-my-coworkers-are-now-my-direct-reports?utm_source=morning_brew" style="text-decoration:none; border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="Make it work image " style="border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/7b6de1bb891bb0dd9e289abb0a591582a5da30e6-1503x603.png?w=670&q=70&auto=format">
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:16px;">
<small>
<em></em>
</small>
</p>
</a>
<div>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><em>Each week, our workplace whisperer Shane Loughnane answers a reader-submitted question about work in 2021. Anything bothering you at work? <a href="https://link.morningbrew.com/click/24880110.2715963/aHR0cHM6Ly9tb3JuaW5nYnJld2RhaWx5LnR5cGVmb3JtLmNvbS90by9mWTFDR3p5WT91dG1fc291cmNlPW1vcm5pbmdfYnJldw/5c881db32ddf9c27c11a8f77Bb6753cbd?utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Ask Shane here</a>.</em></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>I just got promoted to a manager role within my department, and it will be my first time with direct reports. Since I’ve worked with this team for a couple of years already, it feels a bit strange; I already “know” them, and now I’m expected to lead them. How do I move from a peer to a manager successfully?<em>—</em>Emily, PA</strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">During a recent spiral into the depths of on-demand streaming, I found myself captivated by honeybees—as it turns out, a new honeybee is crowned queen only after defeating (via deadly sting) all other candidates in a series of head-to-head battles. That’s certainly one way to assume a leadership role. Alternatively, you might find yourself in the potentially uncomfortable position of being tapped to manage your former peers.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Frankly, the reason it feels a bit strange is because it is—not just for you, but for your team as well. The best thing you can do is to meet it head on: Connect with each of your direct reports to reestablish roles and, if necessary, boundaries. Remember that it’s OK to acknowledge that your relationships will change; indeed, they should if your goal is to best serve them as their manager.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Start building trust by being open about where you think you’re going to need help. It’s important for them to feel like they’re still working <em>with</em> you as much as <em>for</em> you—explain that while you may have added responsibilities, you’re still a part of the team and committed to its success. To that end, take advantage of the fact that you do know your directs. How will you utilize their strengths? What pain points can you eliminate for them? Use that “insider knowledge” to help you find some easy wins.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Remember that you likely have more anxiety about this transition than your team ever will. As a first-time manager, it won’t be perfect. Learn from your mistakes, <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lQMOLWVYxss" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">don't do this</a>, and trust the instincts that earned you this promotion—the rest will take care of itself.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>How do you deal with the Sunday scaries?<em>—</em>Anonymous, Singapore</strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Have you tried picturing Monday in its underwear? On the off chance that old show biz trick doesn’t cure your anxiety, perhaps our readers have some more practical advice they’d be willing to share. Anyone out there have a remedy for the Sunday blues?</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><em>Have a tip for our friend in Singapore or a question about work you want to ask Shane? <a href="https://link.morningbrew.com/click/24880110.2715963/aHR0cHM6Ly9tb3JuaW5nYnJld2RhaWx5LnR5cGVmb3JtLmNvbS90by9mWTFDR3p5WT91dG1fc291cmNlPW1vcm5pbmdfYnJldw/5c881db32ddf9c27c11a8f77Cb6753cbd?utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Write in here</a>. </em></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><em>And coming tomorrow...HR Brew. Be one of the <a href="https://link.morningbrew.com/click/24747517.1107/aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cubW9ybmluZ2JyZXcuY29tL2hyL3N1YnNjcmliZT91dG1fbWVkaXVtPW5ld3NsZXR0ZXImdXRtX3NvdXJjZT1jcm9zc3Byb21vJnV0bV9jYW1wYWlnbj1ocl9pbl9tb3JuaW5nYnJld18wODE0MjE/5c881db32ddf9c27c11a8f77B7b0506f5?utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">first subscribers</a> to our upcoming newsletter on all things human resources.</em></p>
</div>

<tr class="">
<td align="left" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;font-size: 0px; padding: 10px 0px; word-break: break-word;">
<table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;color: #353535; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 13px; line-height: 22px; table-layout: auto; width: 100%; border: none;" width="100%">
<tr>
<td width="33%" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt">
<div style="text-align: center; background: linear-gradient(90deg, #ffe62e 25%, #0f9046); background-color: #1c7ff2; line-height: 4px; font-size: 4px; width: 100%; margin: 20px 0;">
 
</div>
</td>
<td style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;border: 2px solid #353535; background: white; margin: 0px; padding: 10px;">
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;word-break: keep-all; word-wrap: normal; text-align: center; text-transform: uppercase; font-family: Georgia, 'Times New Roman', Times, serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 16px; line-height: 18px; color: #353535; padding: 0px; margin: 0px;">
ANALYSIS
</p>
</td>
<td width="33%" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt">
<div style="text-align: center; background: linear-gradient(90deg, #2b9295, #1c7ff2); background-color: #1c7ff2; line-height: 4px; font-size: 4px; width: 100%; margin: 20px 0;">
 
</div>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="">
<td class="column" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;font-size: 0px; padding: 25px; word-break: break-word;">
<div style="font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;">
<h1 style="margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:24px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left">
Walt Disney’s Failed City of the Future
</h1>
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/10/01/a-brief-history-of-the-epcot-center-and-what-it-was-meant-to-be?utm_source=morning_brew" style="text-decoration:none; border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="Painting of original EPCOT with monorail" style="border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/c90b51339c62636046e99d6e22b38891774c0bfa-768x494.png?w=670&q=70&auto=format">
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:16px;">
<small>
<em>Disney</em>
</small>
</p>
</a>
<div>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">The Magic Kingdom at Disney World opened its doors 50 years ago this week. That’s great and all, but let’s talk about another Disney World anniversary with far more intrigue—the opening of the EPCOT Center on October 1, 1982.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Thing is,<strong> </strong>EPCOT wasn’t supposed to be an amusement park. It was originally proposed as a fully fledged “<a href="https://www.esquire.com/entertainment/news/a35104/walt-disney-epcot-history-city-of-tomorrow/?utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">city of the future</a>,” or, more precisely, an Experimental Prototype Community of Tomorrow (EPCOT).</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>The backstory: </strong>Walt Disney was often frustrated with modern city living. He reportedly grumbled about being woken up by garbage collectors in the morning, and rolled his eyes at the general dirtiness of Los Angeles.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">So, being the guy with the golden ideas (Snow White with <em>seven</em> dwarfs? Brilliant), Walt Disney conceived of a master-planned city that would exist as one pillar of the Disney World complex in Florida. As he explained in a 1966 presentation made for Florida legislators, this city would be a “planned environment demonstrating to the world what American communities can accomplish through proper control of planning and design.”</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">So what would the city look like?</p>
<ul style="line-height:22px">
<li>
<span>
</span><span><strong>It would be circular in shape. </strong></span><span>In the middle you’d find a central hub with a convention center. From there, four other rings of development would fan out with businesses, houses, apartments, and green space.</span>
</li>
<li>
<span>
</span><span><strong>The rail would have mono</strong></span><span>. Disney was obsessed with the monorail, which he introduced in 1959 at a much smaller scale at California’s Disneyland, and was eager to take to his new city.</span>
</li>
<li>
<span>
</span><span><strong>It would be a “company town.”</strong></span><span> All citizens of the </span><span><em>Jetsons</em></span><span>-esque city would be working for the Disney company or businesses that worked with Disney.</span>
</li>
</ul>
<h2 style="margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:18px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left">Dreaming of utopias </h2>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Walt Disney was not the first nor the last ultra-wealthy person who tried to harness the latest technology to create an urban utopia in his vision. In fact, several folks are having a crack at it right now.</p>
<ul style="line-height:22px">
<li>
<span>Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, known as “MBS,” has proposed a $500 billion city-state in the desert, called </span><span><a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/a-princes-500-billion-desert-dream-flying-cars-robot-dinosaurs-and-a-giant-artificial-moon-11564097568?mod=article_inline" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Neom</a></span><span>. If MBS’s plan is realized, employees will take drone taxis to work and Neom’s tech prowess will make Silicon Valley seem like a backwater.</span>
</li>
<li>
<span>And then there’s Telosa, the $400 billion city being planned by </span><span><a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/08/20/icebreakers-withecommerce-mogul-marc-lore?utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">billionaire e-commerce mogul Marc Lore</a></span><span> on the principle of a “reformed vision of capitalism.”</span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Most urban policy experts are skeptical that these utopian dreams will become reality, given the extreme logistical hurdles (and price tags) of starting a city from scratch. After all, Walt Disney’s project fizzled after he died in December 1966.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">The Disney team pivoted to a theme park that, while not itself a city of the future, celebrates human achievement, technological progress, and the promise of dreaming big. —<em>MM</em></p>
</div>

</h1>
<div>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Welcome to Open House, the only newsletter section that dares find out how to <em>really</em> be a Disney adult. We’ll give you a few facts about a listing and you try to guess the price.</p>
<img class="img-responsive" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/e3ee85001788a60ca8d43648bf449ba79fcbb42b-836x482.gif?w=670&q=70&auto=format" alt="Disney House in Orlando, Florida" style="border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;width:100% !important"><p><em>Golden Oak Realty</em></p><p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">In honor of Disney World’s 50th anniversary, we’re heading down to the luxurious <a href="https://www.disneygoldenoak.com/?utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Golden Oak neighborhoods</a> on the premises of Disney’s resort in Orlando, Florida. If you thought the soft pretzels were expensive in Magic Kingdom, this two-story, 4,405 square-foot custom Disney <a href="https://www.disneygoldenoak.com/home-availability/curacao/?utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">home</a> will blow your mind. Amenities include:</p>
<ul style="line-height:22px">
<li><span>6 beds, 6 baths</span></li>
<li><span>Lanai and a heated, screened-in pool</span></li>
<li><span>Unhinged entertainment room where you sit back-to-back with loved ones</span></li>
<li><span>Requirement to join the very expensive neighborhood country club</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">How much to live, breathe, and sleep the Mouse?</p>

<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">3. Mick Jagger went to a dive bar in Charlotte and literally everybody missed him. (<a href="https://jeremymarkovich.substack.com/p/mick-jagger-charlotte-thirsty-beaver?utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">North Carolina Rabbit Hole</a>)</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">4. Inside America’s broken supply chain. (<a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/interactive/2021/supply-chain-issues/?utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Washington Post</a>)</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">5. A table designed specifically for jigsaw puzzles. (<a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=G5VQUDpK9Iw" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Simone Giertz</a>)</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">6. On the internet, we’re always famous. (<a href="https://www.newyorker.com/news/essay/on-the-internet-were-always-famous?mc_cid=d2035e9e35&mc_eid=95deaabb89&utm_source=newsletter&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=newsletter_axiosfutureofwork&stream=future" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">New Yorker</a>)<br><br>7. What it’s like to work 8–10 hours a day in virtual reality. (<a href="https://blog.immersed.team/working-from-orbit-39bf95a6d385?gi=d00dcf324532" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Immersed</a>)</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">8. Chernobyl: How it happened. (<a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ijst4g5KFN0" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">MIT OpenCourseWare</a>)</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">9. How Twitter decided to open up its image-cropping algorithm to the public. (<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/emerging-tech/stories/2021/09/27/behind-the-scenes-of-twitter-s-decision-to-open-up-its-image-cropping-algorithm-to-researchers?curator=MediaREDEF" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Emerging Tech Brew</a>)<br><br>10. (<a href="https://www.buzzsprout.com/1112270/9179249?utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333"><em>You’re Wrong About</em></a>)</p>

#353535;\"\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eGood morning. \u003c/strong\u003eToday’s Editor’s Note is being replaced by a love letter to TikTok, an app that, while not perfect, has brought me a great deal of enjoyment the last few months.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eWhat makes TikTok so refreshing is that it’s one of the few places left where celebrity doesn’t matter. Users respond most to regular people with extraordinary talent (like our very own \u003ca href=\"https://www.tiktok.com/@morningbrew/video/7013107425473465605?is_copy_url=0\u0026is_from_webapp=v1\u0026sender_device=pc\u0026sender_web_id=6897986481718085126\" class=\"link\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eDan Toomey\u003c/a\u003e).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eThis says everything you need to know: The second-most followed person on Instagram is Cristiano Ronaldo. The second-most followed person on TikTok is \u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2021/06/02/style/khaby-lame-tiktok.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eKhaby Lame\u003c/a\u003e, a 21-year-old former factory employee in Italy who hilariously mocks “life hack” videos. Your social currency on TikTok is your ability to create A+ content \u003cem\u003eon TikTok\u003c/em\u003e—it doesn’t matter whether you’re a soccer star or an assembly line worker. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eWhen I ask people why they’re not on TikTok, by far the most common response is, “I fear I’d like it so much that I’d spend all my time on it.” A) That's a ridiculous thing to say and b) come up with a solution because you're missing out.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;font-family:flood-std, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;font-size:16px;font-weight:500\"\u003e—Neal Freyman\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c!-- ARTICLE --\u003e\n\u003ctr class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003ctd align=\"left\" style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;font-size: 0px; background: linear-gradient(90deg, #2b9295, #1c7ff2); background-color: #1c7ff2; line-height: 4px; font-size: 4px; width: 100%; margin: 20px 0;\"\u003e\n \n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003ctr class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003ctd class=\"column\" style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;font-size: 0px; padding: 25px; word-break: break-word;\"\u003e\n\u003cdiv style=\"font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;\"\u003e\n\u003ch1 style=\"margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:24px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left\"\u003e\nIcebreakers With...TikTok Star Nick Cho\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/10/01/icebreakers-with-tiktok-star-nick-cho?utm_source=morning_brew\" style=\"text-decoration:none; border:none;\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"Photo of Nick Cho\" style=\"border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/9ac74e9e4e0f269c212d77dc589dffeaaf6d4d08-2696x1522.jpg?w=670\u0026q=70\u0026auto=format\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:16px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\n\u003cem\u003eNick Cho\u003c/em\u003e\n\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eNick Cho, known as “\u003ca href=\"https://www.tiktok.com/@yourkoreandad?utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eYour Korean Dad\u003c/a\u003e” on TikTok, is a comedian and self-proclaimed “king of weird analogies.” His day job is working at the SF-based \u003ca href=\"https://www.wreckingballcoffee.com/?utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ecoffee chain\u003c/a\u003e he and his wife founded in 2011 but, with almost 3 million followers on TikTok and a newly launched YouTube channel, making wholesome social content is starting to become a full-time job.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eMorning Brew got deep with Nick.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWhat’s on your coffee shop’s playlist?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eBack in 2001 or 2002, when I got my first iPod, I bought it at the store and when I got home I realized it already had music on it. Someone had bought it and returned it. When I looked at the playlist, it was all these hits from the ’80s and ’90s. And that has been my go-to coffee shop playlist for 20 years. There's Guns N' Roses on it. There's Van Halen, Paula Abdul.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eWhenever I'm working at the cafes, it's only a matter of time before the baristas get fed up with the mix. We call it “Kwon's mix” because you know how you can name iPods or iPhones? The iPod was called Kwon’s iPod.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eIf you didn't have to sleep, how would you spend the extra eight hours?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eI would be driving to different places. So I could spend every day somewhere new.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWhat does your typical day look like?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eI don't eat breakfast when I wake up. I make cappuccinos for my wife and for myself—mostly for her. Then I go to the gym. Then I start working on whatever I'm working on. Lately, it's thinking about what to make for my TikTok. I have managers now, like Hollywood management. It's very strange.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eThere’s one thing in my daily routine I feel immensely guilty about, so maybe talking about it will help me process. But, I have to be able to make space to just sort of “be” and either go for a walk or go to the gym or just chill. For example, I don't get massages on a regular basis, but the other day, I was like, I think I need a massage. And I had this flood of ideas that happened while I was getting a massage. And that's super self-indulgent. But for better or for worse, I can't produce if I don't take this time. And it's something that I'm struggling with and trying to figure out right now. You know, it's like Korean guilt. Like, I'm not sweating enough or not working hard enough.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eHow do you manage that guilt?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eThe first thing for me is realizing that guilt is okay. But it's not probably productive or helpful for me to feel too guilty. It’s almost like the Jiminy Cricket on your shoulder or this little voice in your head. We’re not supposed to shut those away.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eAre you someone that, when you are with people, you immediately start asking deep questions?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eYeah, I like to just get into it. That's sort of my style.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eThis interview has been edited and condensed for clarity.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable border=\"0\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;border-collapse: collapse\" width=\"100%\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;padding-top: 12px\"\u003e\n\u003ca rel=\"noopener\" style=\"text-decoration: none\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.facebook.com/sharer.php?u=https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/10/01/icebreakers-with-tiktok-star-nick-cho\u0026utm_source=facebook_share\" class=\"\"\u003e\u003cimg style=\"border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: inline-block; padding: 25px; word-break: break-word;\"\u003e\n\u003cdiv style=\"font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;\"\u003e\n\u003ch1 style=\"margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:24px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left\"\u003e\nI Used to Call Them Coworkers. Now I'm Their Manager.\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/10/01/make-it-work-my-coworkers-are-now-my-direct-reports?utm_source=morning_brew\" style=\"text-decoration:none; border:none;\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"Make it work image \" style=\"border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/7b6de1bb891bb0dd9e289abb0a591582a5da30e6-1503x603.png?w=670\u0026q=70\u0026auto=format\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:16px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\n\u003cem\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\n\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eEach week, our workplace whisperer Shane Loughnane answers a reader-submitted question about work in 2021. Anything bothering you at work? \u003ca href=\"https://link.morningbrew.com/click/24880110.2715963/aHR0cHM6Ly9tb3JuaW5nYnJld2RhaWx5LnR5cGVmb3JtLmNvbS90by9mWTFDR3p5WT91dG1fc291cmNlPW1vcm5pbmdfYnJldw/5c881db32ddf9c27c11a8f77Bb6753cbd?utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eAsk Shane here\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eI just got promoted to a manager role within my department, and it will be my first time with direct reports. Since I’ve worked with this team for a couple of years already, it feels a bit strange; I already “know” them, and now I’m expected to lead them. How do I move from a peer to a manager successfully?\u003cem\u003e—\u003c/em\u003eEmily, PA\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eDuring a recent spiral into the depths of on-demand streaming, I found myself captivated by honeybees—as it turns out, a new honeybee is crowned queen only after defeating (via deadly sting) all other candidates in a series of head-to-head battles. That’s certainly one way to assume a leadership role. Alternatively, you might find yourself in the potentially uncomfortable position of being tapped to manage your former peers.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eFrankly, the reason it feels a bit strange is because it is—not just for you, but for your team as well. The best thing you can do is to meet it head on: Connect with each of your direct reports to reestablish roles and, if necessary, boundaries. Remember that it’s OK to acknowledge that your relationships will change; indeed, they should if your goal is to best serve them as their manager.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eStart building trust by being open about where you think you’re going to need help. It’s important for them to feel like they’re still working \u003cem\u003ewith\u003c/em\u003e you as much as \u003cem\u003efor\u003c/em\u003e you—explain that while you may have added responsibilities, you’re still a part of the team and committed to its success. To that end, take advantage of the fact that you do know your directs. How will you utilize their strengths? What pain points can you eliminate for them? Use that “insider knowledge” to help you find some easy wins.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eRemember that you likely have more anxiety about this transition than your team ever will. As a first-time manager, it won’t be perfect. Learn from your mistakes, \u003ca href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lQMOLWVYxss\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003edon't do this\u003c/a\u003e, and trust the instincts that earned you this promotion—the rest will take care of itself.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eHow do you deal with the Sunday scaries?\u003cem\u003e—\u003c/em\u003eAnonymous, Singapore\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eHave you tried picturing Monday in its underwear? On the off chance that old show biz trick doesn’t cure your anxiety, perhaps our readers have some more practical advice they’d be willing to share. Anyone out there have a remedy for the Sunday blues?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eHave a tip for our friend in Singapore or a question about work you want to ask Shane? \u003ca href=\"https://link.morningbrew.com/click/24880110.2715963/aHR0cHM6Ly9tb3JuaW5nYnJld2RhaWx5LnR5cGVmb3JtLmNvbS90by9mWTFDR3p5WT91dG1fc291cmNlPW1vcm5pbmdfYnJldw/5c881db32ddf9c27c11a8f77Cb6753cbd?utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eWrite in here\u003c/a\u003e. \u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eAnd coming tomorrow...HR Brew. padding: 25px; word-break: break-word;\"\u003e\n\u003cdiv style=\"font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;\"\u003e\n\u003ch1 style=\"margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:24px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left\"\u003e\nWalt Disney’s Failed City of the Future\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/10/01/a-brief-history-of-the-epcot-center-and-what-it-was-meant-to-be?utm_source=morning_brew\" style=\"text-decoration:none; border:none;\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"Painting of original EPCOT with monorail\" style=\"border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/c90b51339c62636046e99d6e22b38891774c0bfa-768x494.png?w=670\u0026q=70\u0026auto=format\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:16px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\n\u003cem\u003eDisney\u003c/em\u003e\n\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eThe Magic Kingdom at Disney World opened its doors 50 years ago this week. That’s great and all, but let’s talk about another Disney World anniversary with far more intrigue—the opening of the EPCOT Center on October 1, 1982.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eThing is,\u003cstrong\u003e \u003c/strong\u003eEPCOT wasn’t supposed to be an amusement park. It was originally proposed as a fully fledged “\u003ca href=\"https://www.esquire.com/entertainment/news/a35104/walt-disney-epcot-history-city-of-tomorrow/?utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ecity of the future\u003c/a\u003e,” or, more precisely, an Experimental Prototype Community of Tomorrow (EPCOT).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eThe backstory: \u003c/strong\u003eWalt Disney was often frustrated with modern city living. He reportedly grumbled about being woken up by garbage collectors in the morning, and rolled his eyes at the general dirtiness of Los Angeles.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eSo, being the guy with the golden ideas (Snow White with \u003cem\u003eseven\u003c/em\u003e dwarfs? Brilliant), Walt Disney conceived of a master-planned city that would exist as one pillar of the Disney World complex in Florida. As he explained in a 1966 presentation made for Florida legislators, this city would be a “planned environment demonstrating to the world what American communities can accomplish through proper control of planning and design.”\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eSo what would the city look like?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul style=\"line-height:22px\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eIt would be circular in shape. \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003eIn the middle you’d find a central hub with a convention center. From there, four other rings of development would fan out with businesses, houses, apartments, and green space.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eThe rail would have mono\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e. Disney was obsessed with the monorail, which he introduced in 1959 at a much smaller scale at California’s Disneyland, and was eager to take to his new city.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eIt would be a “company town.”\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e All citizens of the \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cem\u003eJetsons\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e-esque city would be working for the Disney company or businesses that worked with Disney.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch2 style=\"margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:18px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left\"\u003eDreaming of utopias \u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eWalt Disney was not the first nor the last ultra-wealthy person who tried to harness the latest technology to create an urban utopia in his vision. In fact, several folks are having a crack at it right now.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul style=\"line-height:22px\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eSaudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, known as “MBS,” has proposed a $500 billion city-state in the desert, called \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/a-princes-500-billion-desert-dream-flying-cars-robot-dinosaurs-and-a-giant-artificial-moon-11564097568?mod=article_inline\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eNeom\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e. If MBS’s plan is realized, employees will take drone taxis to work and Neom’s tech prowess will make Silicon Valley seem like a backwater.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eAnd then there’s Telosa, the $400 billion city being planned by \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/08/20/icebreakers-withecommerce-mogul-marc-lore?utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ebillionaire e-commerce mogul Marc Lore\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e on the principle of a “reformed vision of capitalism.”\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eMost urban policy experts are skeptical that these utopian dreams will become reality, given the extreme logistical hurdles (and price tags) of starting a city from scratch. After all, Walt Disney’s project fizzled after he died in December 1966.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eThe Disney team pivoted to a theme park that, while not itself a city of the future, celebrates human achievement, technological progress, and the promise of dreaming big. —\u003cem\u003eMM\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable border=\"0\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;border-collapse: collapse\" width=\"100%\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;padding-top: 12px\"\u003e\n\u003ca rel=\"noopener\" style=\"text-decoration: none\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.facebook.com/sharer.php?u=https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/10/01/a-brief-history-of-the-epcot-center-and-what-it-was-meant-to-be\u0026utm_source=facebook_share\" class=\"\"\u003e\u003cimg style=\"border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: inline-block;
